messages: b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:35): aargh. I broke livedom.validator.nu
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (15:47): wow. Glazman blog rendering prked in latest Minefield
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (15:47): http://www.glazman.org/weblog/
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (15:47): on Linux at least, in my environment
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (15:51): sayrer: you awake?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (16:09): in my minefield, glazou looks like this:
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (16:09): http://people.w3.org/mike/gecko/glazou.png
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:10): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: WFM using a recentish build with html5.enable
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:11): Oh, my build seems to be way more out of date than I thought
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (16:11): this is with very latest minefield -- today or yesterday
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (16:11): and same thing with html5.enabled false
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (16:21): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea, doesn't Minefield do automatic updates for you every day?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:22): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: I see the problem - the text is yucky and un-antialiased :-(
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (16:22): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: you can turn that auto-update thing off
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (16:22): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: good eye!
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (16:22): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2, ok. Why would you, though?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (16:23): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: because it's stupid?
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (16:23): is that a question or a statement?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:23): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: It offers to upgrade every day but I often ignore it
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (16:23): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: are you asking or making a suggestion?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:24): Are we playing questions?
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (16:24): Mine automatically downloads the updates and installs them whenever I restart.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (16:24): tries to write Ruby
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:25): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: Which kind of Ruby?
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (16:25): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554, that's a very short word to write, but well done. You succeeded.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (16:26): ph
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (16:26): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: The shiny one
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (16:26): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea, we were playing a game?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:27): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: Animal, vegetable, or mineral?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (16:28): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: The shiny one.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:29): So a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 is writing a Ruby that is a shiny animal?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (16:29): Yes.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (16:29): (And I'm saying that just because Hixie can't, because he says he never lies)
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:30): Couldn't that be a lie?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (16:36): Hah! No wonder he's doing so well at controlling the future of the intarwebs!
86123bebfedc05009c27d1ac8f8c7411 (16:47): is <b> and <i> actually going to be left in html5?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (16:52): Why wouldn't they be?

86123bebfedc05009c27d1ac8f8c7411 (16:54): seems they is all ready represented by <strong> for example. And it doesn't seem to be a good example for when to use them. Or why would the specs say this: "In the previous example, the correct element to use would have been strong, not b."?
86123bebfedc05009c27d1ac8f8c7411 (16:55): uhm... nevermind that quote :)

86123bebfedc05009c27d1ac8f8c7411 (17:14): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: but given there definition how is the names of them motivated? <aside>, <article> and so on describes their intended use. How does <b> describe it's use? Or isn't that important?
d114be1698421a7cec050e2207d29631 (17:16): 86123bebfedc05009c27d1ac8f8c7411: how does b not describe it's intended use?
86123bebfedc05009c27d1ac8f8c7411 (17:16): Sorry if I'm bringing up already discussed stuff. Haven't read up on my html5 :/

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:21): So I have a problem. I have a test harness which loads testcases into an iframe. It is not impossible that those testcases will cause infinite loops or other bad behaviour so it would be nice to be able to set a timeout and kill the script if the timeout is reached
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:22): Howwever this doesn't seem to be easy; the event loop seems to prioritise running the existing script above anything else.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:22): (run to completion I guess)

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (17:22): 86123bebfedc05009c27d1ac8f8c7411, b is intended for use cases which are commenly represented typographically in bold text, but for which no specific semantic element exists

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (17:23): 86123bebfedc05009c27d1ac8f8c7411, it would be unreasonable to have to create separate semantic elements to individually cover each of those cases, when it wouldn't gain any benefit over using the generic element
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:23): Is there some way I force the source of the iframe to change before the testcase script has finished running?
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (17:23): similarly for the i element

86123bebfedc05009c27d1ac8f8c7411 (17:23): d114be1698421a7cec050e2207d29631: from what I understand it's not intended to represent bold text but rather like f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 just wrote "text usually written in bold"
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:23): (or close the window with the iframe in or delete the iframe or something, as long as it causes the script to die)

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (17:24): 86123bebfedc05009c27d1ac8f8c7411, the names are retained for backwards compatibility reasons. It's best not to read too much into just the name of the element. It's the definition that matters mose
86123bebfedc05009c27d1ac8f8c7411 (17:25): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: that explanation was good :) Not sure I'm agreeing with you but still.
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (17:25): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: I'm guessing that setTimeout() isn't being your friend

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (17:25): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea, I don't know of any way to achieve that, unless perhaps setting the iframe's window.location to a new page interrupts any scripts running within the iframe
86123bebfedc05009c27d1ac8f8c7411 (17:25): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: I got that backward compatiblility reason :) Just not a big fan of that either.
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (17:26): 86123bebfedc05009c27d1ac8f8c7411, it's really just a matter of being pragmatic over theoretical purity
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:26): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: setting the <iframe>.src doesn't
86123bebfedc05009c27d1ac8f8c7411 (17:26): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: have nothing to do today and haven't been reading much about html5 so I'm catching up.
86123bebfedc05009c27d1ac8f8c7411 (17:26): I'm not intending to start an argument
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (17:26): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea, what about iframe.contentWindow.location?
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (17:27): 86123bebfedc05009c27d1ac8f8c7411, no worries. You've been much more pleasant and understanding than the person I debated this with over twitter 2 days ago
86123bebfedc05009c27d1ac8f8c7411 (17:28): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: I'm not really bothered with html5 having it, but I can imagine it being missused.
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (17:28): indeed. It will be.
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (17:29): I'm not sure it makes any difference if it's "misused"
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (17:29): the idea that <strong> is more accessible than <b> in any way is a red herring
86123bebfedc05009c27d1ac8f8c7411 (17:30): b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f: but <b> will still give bold text I assume?
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (17:30): just like <strong> does
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (17:30): they are equivalent on the vast mojority of pages
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (17:30): except those select few which change default styling for either
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:31): mutters about how badly designed the 'this' semantics are in javascript
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:32): Hmm, deleting the iframe seems to work well
86123bebfedc05009c27d1ac8f8c7411 (17:32): b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f: but still, <strong> have semantic meaning while <b> doesn't. From what I understand
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (17:32): they both have meaning
86123bebfedc05009c27d1ac8f8c7411 (17:33): * just not as clear semantic meaning then :)
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (17:33): I'm not sure <strong> has a particularly clear meaning either
86123bebfedc05009c27d1ac8f8c7411 (17:33): it have a better meaning for me at least. But that doesn't really say anything
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (17:34): they're basically synonyms, discussing which one is "better" seems to be a waste of everyone's time
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (17:34): I seem to have acquired a stronger view on this than I used to have. :)
d114be1698421a7cec050e2207d29631 (17:35): i've developed the strong view that it just doesn't matter
86123bebfedc05009c27d1ac8f8c7411 (17:35): b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f: I'm doing my best on wasting my time on meanless stuff right now. Third day on my "time off"

b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (17:38): I really wish people had never used the word "semantic" in conjunction with the web, "meaning" is much less opaque and you couldn't get consturctions like "semantic meaning"
86123bebfedc05009c27d1ac8f8c7411 (17:40): But I'll stop bothering you now
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (17:41): 86123bebfedc05009c27d1ac8f8c7411, without <i>, which element would you use to mark up a ship name, which is conventionally rendered in italics?
86123bebfedc05009c27d1ac8f8c7411 (17:43): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: <title>, <name> or something similar. But yes. It would be a challange to figure out what that element should be named
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (17:43): so you're advocating creating a new element for each case like that?
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (17:43): even though there are potentially dozens of such cases?
86123bebfedc05009c27d1ac8f8c7411 (17:43): no, not really. Haven thought about it that much
86123bebfedc05009c27d1ac8f8c7411 (17:44): It just feels like there should be a better name for <i> then i
86123bebfedc05009c27d1ac8f8c7411 (17:44): but I guess there isn't
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (17:44): a better name for representating traditioanlly italicised text than "italic"? :)
86123bebfedc05009c27d1ac8f8c7411 (17:45): it seems there should ba a name for the italic "meaning"
86123bebfedc05009c27d1ac8f8c7411 (17:45): *should be
86123bebfedc05009c27d1ac8f8c7411 (17:46): doesn't like his new espresso.
86123bebfedc05009c27d1ac8f8c7411 (17:46): I should buy new

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (17:52): Reading Shelly's latest on www-archive, it seems she prefers to work under the assumption that Microsoft isn't acting in good faith and has convinced her self that they're going to object to everything as soon as we try to go to LC
